comments.commentBody:
Oh dear, no comments yet.
First, my thanks to all who helped me with Tuesday's puzzle - suejean, Warren HH - If Aries is linked to spring, can we blame the ram for the snow that we expect tomorrow?
MOL - beautiful moon pictures, I missed the red moon; does that only appear every 18 years?
While I didn't have a Natick or DNF, per usual, there are things I don't understand - like 15A - I tried saying it out loud, Deb, but no AHA moment!
Of course, I didn't find either quote - are they anagrams?
I did hear something special on PBS tonight -
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-a8ELOVig4
it made me feel understood, yet sad... your reactions?
John from Chicago - you have an amazing memory - I loved the quotes from Casablanca - one of my all-time favorite movies.
If there is one Latin quote embedded in the ** answers that doesn't use all the letters, then I've conquered that one.  But the English quote - not yet!  Oh, so clever, Will Nediger!

Those blasted Spanish bears, again. The word has gender. I had to rerun the puzzle to correct my initial wrong guess. I am listening to a lecture series on Bronze Age civilizations in the region, and Edom was mentioned, and I should have seen that the cheese had to be wrong.

Strange solving experience; the theme did not help in the least, except in solving 54A. I see the Latin quote, but am still ransacking my brain for a well known English quotation, as it is clearly not just the translation. And not "Et tu Brute?"

Let me add two more reasons to the growing catalogue of why manhole covers are round, or should be round if they are not.

One is wear and tear. A circular rim experiences the least wear of all possible shapes. Any covers with corners will abrade and wear most at the corners until they ultimately become circles. By the same token, a manhole port having the shape of a circle will experience the least local stress and be less likely to crack, as at a corner, as others have pointed out earlier.

Another is symmetry. In the absence of gravity (such as on the space shuttle) the reason for the shape now becomes one of convenience, and it is nice to be able to open and close a manhole port without having to orient the cover in any special direction. This absence of a preferred direction argues for rotational symmetry, i.e., a circle. Also pointed out by others.

I'm also trying to work myself into the metaphysics of manholes. The universe, so far as we know, has no preferred orientation or helicity, so the four-dimensional space-time equivalent of a manhole is probably a 3-dimensional sphere in 4-dimensional hyperspace, much as the ordiinary manhole is a 2-dimensional circle in 3-dimensional real world space.

Well, if, after all that, Gary Antonick comes up with a totally different and new answer, it sure had better be a doozy. It is now midnight and I am going to bed. I'll try not to count sheep jumping into manholes. :)

PS: This reminds me of the story of a little child learning about areas of circles from her father. "No, daddy," she protested, "pies are round!"

Just one more:  if yu want a working manhole without a flange and also workable without gravity, you want a disc to screw into the manhole.  The only shape that allows a screw thread on the rim and in the hole  is a circle.  G'night!!!
What were the patient's testosterone levels?  Could she have a testosterone secreting ovarian (or other) lesion or could it be exogenous?

My husband and I are both 46 and have been married for almost 14 years. I have to say that the young kid years were the worst for sex -- often too tired, too many demands on us. Sometimes a few months would go by without sex. Now that our kids are getting older and more self-sufficient (11 and almost 7) sex frequency is increasing. They can go downstairs Saturday morning to watch cartoons and feed themselves breakfast, and we can have the upstairs to ourselves for an hour or more. That didn't happen during the toddler years.

I'm also (dare I say it?) looking forward to my fifties after I've gone through menopause. Not having periods any more will mean more opportunities for sex, and also not having to deal with birth control anymore.

A few more tips on nutritional support for menopausal symptoms, including hot flashes:

Coconut oil (premium, unrefined, virgin)- Two tablespoons a day is recommended. According to Chinese medicine, coconut oil is a Yin food, which can help balance a woman's declining Yin energy, which brings on hot flashes. It also smells good and tastes great. It does not raise cholesterol levels as it is cholesterol neutral.

Vitamin B complex- which is depleted during hot flashes and night sweats.

Vitamin E

Also, reduce stress and work out or communicate any stored anger, which can trigger hot flashes. Physical exercise, like yoga or swimming, greatly reduces frequency of hot flashes, since it also helps reduce stress.

In response to Maggie, post #121--Your words resonated with me. What you wrote about your brother's experience reminded me of my mother's. You wrote: ".... That doctor shredded any hope that might have existed in my brother's imagination.......and nothing else anyone said to him seemed to matter. Would he have lived longer if he had not been given that death sentence? Who knows. But at least he would have had some shard of hope to push him forward to live."

I pondered the question you posed many times, sometimes still do. At the very least my mother would have been able to better enjoy the time she had left if the medical people hadn't shattered all hope. I will never forget her response to the person who gave her the bad news, "So, you've given up on me already?" From the beginning of her diagnosis to the end, the medical establishment treated her as though she was as good as dead. My heart still aches because she suffered more than she had to because of this.

Your comment and other posts here about hope remind me of a Langston Hughe's poem which I paraphrase substituting hope for dreams. "“Hold fast to hope for if hope dies, life is a broken winged bird that cannot fly.”"
Perhaps the truth is that she wants sex, just not you anymore, but if she had four husbands, you could all be happy.

Maybe the Big Love thing is not such a bad idea.

My wife wants sex about ¼ of the time I do. If I only had four wives we could all be happy.

Some people seem to think that a statistic is a fact the same way that "California borders on Nevada" is a fact. Far from it. Gould was not "deluded" to believe that intelligence, determination and quality of care could make a big difference. There's always room for one more at the tail.

Over 60 and not getting enough. I don't know who you women are that are losing your sexual desire or slowing down, but I am not one of them. With kids gone, I have so much energy and a partner who found internet porn. I meet a lot of men in my life and get asked out a lot. I am thinking of leaving this relationship for someone who wants the real thing. Internet porn changed my life and not for the better. We were hot and heavy until suddenly, one day, it stopped.
Humm...  Just a WAG, but how much time does she spend practicing the violin? Is it possible that she's seriously over-stressing the muscles involved, perhaps through incorrect technique?
Her diet?
Is it myositis?

Let's try something that would make the exhaustive, expensive evaluation appear unnecessary in the end.  How about traction alopecia from wearing her hair in a ponytail, with the elevated CPK and hepatic transaminases being an unfortunate red herring.
McArdle's?
Aldolase level?
Was any genetic testing performed to check for abnormalities or mutations? Did the child present with any skin abnormalities or rashes?
Has she been exposed to any medications, toxins, vitamins, new skin lotions, live in a house with lead paint?
Aldolase level? Wondering about juvenile polymyositis. Consider muscle biopsy
*Lots* of violin practice, too much rosin dust on hands and hair, and a worried Mom = no disease.

I don't think the research results discussed in this article would surprise many experienced athletes and coaches. They talk about "the game slowing down" for a player as he or she gains experience. The phenomenon is not about athletic prowess, it's about sizing up situations, anticipating what will happen next, and acting on that information before casual observers understand what's going on. With experience, this process becomes nearly instantaneous.
I'm not a doctor, but couldn't chemo drugs cause these side effects (hair loss, high liver enzymes)?  I'm sure it's not the right answer, but I'll go with accidental chemo drug ingestion.

Was a fungal culture taken of her scalp?
Is she on an antifungal medication?
Is her urine normal?
